default.R: This item is recyclable. Ensure it is clean, dry, and free from food residue before placing it in the recycling bin.
default.O: This item is organic waste. If your city offers compost collection, use the green bin. Otherwise, dispose of it in regular trash.

New York.R: Place clean recyclables in the blue bin. Includes bottles, cans, rigid plastics, paper, and cardboard. No plastic bags, films, or styrofoam.
New York.O: Place organic waste in the brown bin if participating in NYC’s composting program. Includes food scraps, plant waste, and soiled paper.

San Francisco.R: Use the blue bin for recyclables: clean paper, cardboard, metal cans, glass bottles, and hard plastics. No plastic bags or utensils.
San Francisco.O: Place food scraps, napkins, and compostable packaging in the green compost bin. Composting is mandatory in SF.

Los Angeles.R: Recyclables include clean plastic bottles, paper, cardboard, glass, and aluminum cans. Place them loose in the blue bin — no bags.
Los Angeles.O: Organic waste such as food scraps and yard trimmings go in the green bin. Composting is mandatory under LA's Zero Waste program.

Chicago.R: Use the blue cart for recyclables: paper, cardboard, glass, metal cans, and plastic bottles #1–5. Do not bag recyclables.
Chicago.O: Composting is not provided citywide. Use private composting services or dispose of food waste in the black trash cart.

Seattle.R: Recycle paper, cardboard, bottles, cans, and rigid plastics. No food or liquid. Do not bag recyclables.
Seattle.O: Put food waste and soiled paper in the green compost cart. Composting is mandatory for all residences and businesses.

Austin.R: Recycle clean paper, cardboard, metal, glass, and hard plastic. No plastic bags or Styrofoam.
Austin.O: Place food scraps and compostable items in the green organics cart if enrolled. Yard trimmings are accepted.

Boston.R: Recyclables include clean paper, cardboard, glass, metal cans, and plastics #1, #2, #5. No plastic bags or greasy containers.
Boston.O: Curbside composting is expanding. Otherwise, organic waste should be bagged and put in trash.

Philadelphia.R: Recycle clean paper, cardboard, plastic bottles, metal cans, and glass jars. Do not bag recyclables or include food waste.
Philadelphia.O: Composting is not yet citywide. Food waste should go in the trash unless using private compost services.

Houston.R: Recycle clean bottles, cans, paper, and cardboard in the green bin. Plastic bags and Styrofoam are not accepted.
Houston.O: Composting is not citywide. Organic waste should be disposed of in the trash unless using private compost services.

Denver.R: Blue cart: clean paper, cardboard, glass, cans, and plastic containers #1–7. No plastic bags or food waste.
Denver.O: Green compost cart: food scraps, yard waste, and compostable paper products. Composting is voluntary but widely used.

Miami.R: Recyclables include plastic bottles, metal cans, glass, cardboard, and paper. No plastic bags or contaminated items.
Miami.O: Composting is not provided citywide. Food waste should be placed in the trash unless composting privately.

Portland.R: Recycle paper, cardboard, plastic containers, glass, and metal. No plastic bags or lids.
Portland.O: Use the green bin for all food waste, soiled paper, and yard debris. Composting is mandatory for single-family homes.

Washington D.C..R: Recycle paper, cardboard, metal cans, plastic bottles, and glass. Do not bag recyclables.
Washington D.C..O: Food waste can be composted via drop-off locations. A citywide curbside composting program is under development.

Atlanta.R: Recyclables include clean paper, plastic bottles, glass, and metal cans. No plastic bags or foam containers.
Atlanta.O: Composting is available through private programs. Food waste should go in the trash unless composted privately.

Pennsylvania.R: Recyclables in most Pennsylvania municipalities include clean plastic bottles (#1 and #2), paper, cardboard, metal cans, and glass containers. Check with your local authority for accepted materials.
Pennsylvania.O: Organic waste recycling is limited. Residents are encouraged to compost food and yard waste at home or use private services where available.
